elements.content: The 2,6-py(CH2-pz)2 ligand was used to prepare metal complexes as follows:  [py(CH2pz)2](BiI3), {Ag[py(CH2pz)2](OTf)·CH3CN}∞, {PtCl[py(CH2pz)2]}(BF4), {Cd[py(CH2pz)2]2}(BF4)2·[4,4‘-bipy]·0.5H2O, and {Cd[phen]3}2(BF4)4·[py(CH2pz)2]·5H2O (py = pyridyl, pz = pyrazolyl, and phen = 1,10-phenanthroline). The solid state structures of each complex show that all five compounds are organized by noncovalent forces into complex extended structures. Each structure has a common supramolecular organizational feature between the ligands of a cooperative offset face-to-face π−π stacking and C−H···π interaction formed from both the pyridyl and the pyrazolyl rings that is termed the aryl−pyrazolyl embrace. The systematic analysis of this synthon showed that the π−π stacking component of the aryl−pyrazolyl embrace always involves rings of the same type.

The solid state structures of each complex show that all five compounds are organized by noncovalent forces into complex extended structures. Each structure has a common supramolecular organizational feature between the ligands of a cooperative offset face-to-face π-π stacking and C-H⋅⋅⋅π interaction formed from both the pyridyl and the pyrazolyl rings that is termed the aryl-pyrazolyl embrace. The systematic analysis of this synthon showed that the π-π stacking component of the aryl-pyrazolyl embrace always involves rings of the same type.

elements.content: The understanding and control of intra- and intermolecular forces and of the supramolecular self-assembly process are prerequisites for the progress of crystal engineering, defined as “the modeling, synthesis and evaluation of the properties of crystalline materials obtained from inorganic, organometallic and bioinorganic building blocks”. Advances in this field are based on finding reliable supramolecular synthons that can be used to formulate an algorithmic approach to the design of solids. Hydrogen bonding is a widely used tool in crystal engineering because its directionality and robustness make its associative protocol possible to be transferred from one system to another. Various motifs of hydrogen bonding were documented by Allan et al. based on a thorough search of the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD). For the 75 hydrogen bonding motifs revealed, they presented both the geometrical descriptions of the interactions and their probability of formation. From these 75 motifs of hydrogen bonding, some occur in less than 1% of cases while some have a probability of formation of almost 100%.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The understanding and control of intra- and intermolecular forces and of the supramolecular self-assembly process are prerequisites for the progress of crystal engineering, defined as "the modeling, synthesis and evaluation of the properties of crystalline materials obtained from inorganic, organometallic and bioinorganic building blocks". Advances in this field are based on finding reliable supramolecular synthons that can be used to formulate an algorithmic approach to the design of solids. Hydrogen bonding is a widely used tool in crystal engineering because its directionality and robustness make its associative protocol possible to be transferred from one system to another. Various motifs of hydrogen bonding were documented by Allan et al. based on a thorough search of the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD). For the 75 hydrogen bonding motifs revealed, they presented both the geometrical descriptions of the interactions and their probability of formation. From these 75 motifs of hydrogen bonding, some occur in less than 1% of cases while some have a probability of formation of almost 100%.

elements.content: Another supramolecular motif was introduced by Ian Dance and was first called “phenyl embrace”. It consists of a concerted set of interactions between phenyl groups through a combination of offset face-to-face π−π stacking and C−H···π interactions. They are attractive in nature, having energies up to 16 kcal/mol. This intermolecular arrangement was first observed in phenylated moieties of the formula [PPh4]+ and then extended to other aromatic systems such as 2,2‘-bipyridine, terpyridine, and 1,10-phenanthroline; therefore, the generic term was changed to “aryl embrace”. Later, it was observed that similar interactions occur in systems where the aromatic moieties were connected through flexible spacers. Studies on the probability of formation of this supramolecular motif were performed on chemical species of the general formula −EPh3 (where E = any tetrahedral atom), and a wide range of values were found, from 0 to 62%, depending on the central atom, showing the robustness of the aryl embrace as a supramolecular motif.

elements.content: We have recently shown that a similar motif is present in 25% of all cases containing X(pz)2M (where X = B or C, pz = pyrazolyl ring, and M = metal or metalloid) units, termed the pyrazolyl embrace, and we have detailed the geometric requirements (Scheme ) for such an interaction.

Geometric Parameters Associated with the Pyrazolyl Embrace a

a  Ct = ring centroid, R n = ring normal, β = angle between the ring normal and centroid−centroid vector, θ = C−H−Ct angle in C−H···π interactions. Carbon and hydrogen atoms are represented as gray spheres, nitrogen is represented as cross-hatched spheres, and boron/carbon are represented as spheres with horizontal line fill and metal/metalloid as large empty spheres; for further details, see ref .

elements.content: The similarity between the geometrical parameters of both the aryl and the pyrazolyl embrace raised the question if such interactions can occur in systems containing both pyrazolyl rings and pyridine/phenanthroline moieties. In an attempt to prepare complexes with mixed aryl−pyrazolyl embraces, we have carried out a series of reactions using the known 2,6-C5H3N(CH2−C3H3N2)2 ([py(CH2pz)2]) ligand, either alone or in combination with other aromatic nitrogen containing ligands such as 4,4‘-bipyridine and phenathroline, with a variety of metallic centers, each that have different coordination preferences. We wished to test if the different coordination preferences of the various metals have an impact on the occurrence (or the lack) of mixed aryl−pyrazolyl embraces and were also interested in the types of complexes formed by this relatively unexplored ligand bonded to very different types of metal centers.

elements.content: General Considerations. Preparations and crystallizations were carried out in air, unless otherwise indicated. When dry solvents were needed, they were dried using conventional methods and distilled prior to use. Commercially available materials [bismuth(III) iodide (Alfa Aesar), pyrazole, 2,6-pyridinedimethanol, silver trifluoromethanesulfonate, cadmium tetrafluoroborate (45 wt % solution in water), 4,4‘-bipyridine, and 1,10-phenanthroline (Aldrich), and p-toluenesulfonyl chloride (Fisher)] were used as received. Caution! Cadmium compounds and their wastes are extremely toxic and must be handled carefully!
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 General Considerations. Preparations and crystallizations were carried out in air, unless otherwise indicated. When dry solvents were needed, they were dried using conventional methods and distilled prior to use. Commercially available materials [bismuth(III) iodide (Alfa Aesar), pyrazole, 2,6-pyridinedimethanol, silver trifluoromethanesulfonate, cadmium tetrafluoroborate (45 wt % solution in water), 4,4‘-bipyridine, and 1,10-phenanthroline (Aldrich), and p-toluenesulfonyl chloride (Fisher)] were used as received. Caution! Cadmium compounds and their wastes are extremely toxic and must be handled carefully!

elements.content: Synthesis of [py(CH 2 pz) 2 ] (L). To a stirred solution of 2,6-pyridinedimethanol (2.78 g, 0.020 mol) and NaOH (8.0 g, 0.20 mol) in THF/water (75/75 mL) was added a solution of p-toluenesulfonyl chloride (7.61 g, 0.040 mol) in THF (75 mL) at 0 °C. After 4 h of stirring, the mixture was poured into 200 mL of water and extracted with methylene chloride (4 × 75 mL). The organic phase was washed with saturated aqueous NaCl solution and distilled water and dried (Na2SO4), and then, the solvent was removed under vacuum to afford 2,6-pyridine-dimethylene-ditosylate (7.25 g, 81%) as a white powder. In a separate flask (under a nitrogen atmosphere) to a suspension of NaH (0.77 g, 0.032 mol) in dry THF (50 mL) was added dropwise, at 0 °C, a solution of pyrazole (2.20 g, 0.032 mol) in dry THF (50 mL). After 15 min of stirring, a clear solution of Napz was obtained. To this solution was added a solution of pyridine-ditosylate derivative (7.25 g, 0.016 mol) in dry THF (75 mL), the mixture was stirred overnight and filtered, and the solvent was removed to afford 3.52 g (91%) of pure ligand as a pale yellow oil that solidifies in time. 1H NMR (acetone-d 6):  δ:  7.77, 7.50 (d, d, J = 2.1, 1.5 Hz, 2, 2H, 3,5-H pz), 7.64 (t, J = 8.31 Hz, 1H, py), 6.85 (d, J = 8.31, 2H, py), 6.30 (dd, J = 2.1, J = 1.5 Hz, 2H, 4-H pz), 5.45 (s, 4H, PyCH 2 pz). Calcd for C13H13N5:  C, 65.25; H, 5.48. Found:  C, 65.48; H, 5.18.

elements.content: Synthesis and Crystallization of [py(CH 2 pz) 2 ](BiI 3 ) (1). To a stirred solution of BiI3 (0.147 g, 0.25 mmol) in boiling acetonitrile (50 mL) was added a solution of L (0.059 g, 0.25 mmol) in acetonitrile (25 mL). After 15 min of stirring, the orange−red solution was filtered to remove any solid material and placed in a beaker covered with aluminum foil. Red−orange single crystals formed overnight, which were filtered and air-dried (the yield of crystalline material was 0.124 g, 60%). 1H NMR (acetone-d 6, all br):  δ:  7.55 (4H, 3,5-H pz), 7.32 (1H, py), 6.51 (2H, py), 6.02 (2H, 4-H pz), 5.65 (4H, PyCH 2pz). Anal. calcd for C13H13BiI3N5:  C, 18.84; H, 1.58. Found:  C, 19.05; H, 1.23.

elements.content: Synthesis and Crystallization of {Ag[py(CH 2 pz) 2 ](OTf)·CH 3 CN} ∞ (2). To a stirred solution of AgO3SCF3 (AgOTf) (0.064 g, 0.25 mmol) in acetonitrile (10 mL) was added a solution of L (0.059 g, 0.25 mmol) in acetonitrile (5 mL). After 15 min of stirring, the clear solution was left to stand undisturbed. Colorless single crystals deposited after several days, which were filtered and air-dried (the yield of crystalline material was 0.093 g, 76%). 1H NMR (acetone-d 6):  δ:  8.12, 7.78, (d, d, J = 2.3, 1.7 Hz, 2, 2H, 3,5-H pz), 8.06 (t, J = 7.8, 1H, py), 7.62 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 2H, py), 6.44 (dd, J = 2.3, J = 1.7 Hz, 2H, 4-H pz), 5.85 (s, 4H, PyCH 2pz), 2.78 (s, 3H, CH 3CN). Anal. calcd for C16H16AgF3N6O3S:  C, 35.77; H, 3.00. Found:  C, 35.34; H, 2.53.

elements.content: Synthesis and Crystallization of {PtCl[py(CH 2 pz) 2 ]}(BF 4 ) (3). To a suspension of K2[PtCl4] (0.104 g, 0.25 mmol) in nitromethane was added a solution of L (0.059 g, 0.25 mmol) in nitromethane and an excess of solid NaBF4 (0.109 g, 1.0 mmol). The mixture was heated at reflux overnight and filtered, and the solvent was evaporated, to leave an off white solid. The solid was taken back in the minimum amount of nitromethane and crystallized by diethyl ether vapor diffusion (yield of crystalline material was 0.065 g, 47%). 1H NMR (acetone-d 6):  δ:  8.43 (t, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H, py), 8.37, 8.04 (d, d, J = 3.0, 1.8 Hz, 2, 2H, 3,5-H pz), 8.10 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 2H, py), 6.69 (d, J = 5.4 Hz, 2H, 4-H pz), 6.69 (s, 4H, PyCH 2pz). Anal. calcd for C13H13BClF4N5Pt:  C, 28.05; H, 2.35. Found:  C, 28.12; H, 2.38.

elements.content: Synthesis and Crystallization of {Cd[py(CH 2 pz) 2 ] 2 }(BF 4 ) 2 ·[4,4‘-bipy] · 0.5H 2 O (4). To a stirred solution of Cd(BF4)2 in water (45 wt % solution, d = 1.485) (0.107 mL, 0.25 mmol) was added a solution of L (0.059 g, 0.25 mmol) in ethanol (5 mL) and then a solution of 4,4‘-bipy (0.039 g, 0.25 mmol) in ethanol (5 mL). After 15 min of stirring, the clear solution was left to stand undisturbed. Colorless single crystals deposited after several days, which were filtered and air-dried (the yield of crystalline material was 0.147 g, 63%). 1H NMR (acetone-d 6, all br):  δ 8.88 (4H, bipy) 7.95, 7.85 (4,4H, 3,5-H pz), 7.78 (4H, bipy), 6.42 (6H, py), 6.02 (4H, 4-H pz), 5.85 (8H, PyCH 2pz). Anal. calcd for C36H35B2CdF8N12O0.5:  C, 46.50; H, 3.79. Found:  C, 46.88; H, 3.89.

elements.content: Crystal Structure Determinations. X-ray intensity data were measured at 150 K on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD-based diffractometer (Mo Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å). Raw area detector data frame integration and Lorentz/polarization corrections were carried out with SAINT+. Final unit cell parameters are based on the least-squares refinement of all reflections with I > 5σ(I) from each data set. Analysis of the data showed negligible crystal decay during collection. Empirical absorption corrections were applied with SADABS. Direct methods structure solution, difference Fourier calculations, and full-matrix least-squares refinement against F 2 were performed with SHELXTL.

Empirical absorption corrections were applied with SADABS. Direct methods structure solution, difference Fourier calculations, and full-matrix least-squares refinement against F 2 were performed with SHELXTL.

elements.content: [py(CH2pz)2](BiI3) crystallizes in the space group P21/n. Nonhydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters; hydrogen atoms were placed in idealized positions and included as riding atoms with refined isotropic displacement parameters.

elements.content: {Ag[py(CH2pz)2]}(OTf)·CH3CN crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c as determined by the pattern of systematic absences in the intensity data. All atoms are on positions of general crystallographic symmetry. Nonhydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters; hydrogen atoms were placed in idealized positions and included as riding atoms with refined isotropic displacement parameters.

elements.content: {Cd[py(CH2pz)2]2}(BF4)2·[4,4‘-bipy]·0.5H2O crystallizes in the space group I2/a (nonstandard setting of C2/c) as determined by systematic absences in the intensity data and by the successful solution and refinement of the data. The asymmetric unit consists of half of the {Cd[py(CH2pz)2]}2+ complex located on a 2-fold rotational axis; half of a 4,4‘-bipyridine molecule located on an inversion center, the BF4 - anion, and a region of disordered solvent. The solvent guests were modeled as three independent oxygen atoms of water molecules. Occupancies for the three atoms were fixed at values providing reasonable displacement parameters. Hydrogen atoms were not located or calculated for these species. All nonhydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters except the solvents (isotropic); hydrogen atoms attached to carbon were placed in idealized positions and included as riding atoms.

elements.content: Systematic absences in the intensity data for {Cd[phen]3}2(BF4)4·[py(CH2pz)2]·5H2O indicated the space groups P2/c and Pc; intensity statistics strongly suggested an acentric structure. An excellent solution obtained in Pc was verified by manual inspection of the finished structure as well as by PLATON/ADDSYM. The asymmetric unit contains two independent Cd(phen)3 2+ complexes, one uncoordinated [py(CH2pz)2 ligand, four independent BF4 - counterions, and five independent water molecules. Two of the tetrafluoroborate anions [B(3) and B(4)] are disordered over two nearby positions, each in the ratio of 60/40. Occupancies were set for these species to provide reasonable displacement parameters, and a total of 63 restraints (SHELX SAME) were used in holding the geometries of both disorder components of each anion to be similar to that of the ordered anion B1. Hydrogen atoms for the five water molecules were located in the difference map and refined isotropically subject to SHELX “same O−H distance” restraints (SADI, 10 restraints) with the exception of O5, for which Uiso, H were treated as riding. All nonhydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters; hydrogen atoms attached to carbon were placed in idealized positions and included as riding atoms. At convergence, the absolute structure (Flack) parameter was −0.01(1), indicating the absence of inversion twinning. For all of the compounds described here, crystal data and structure refinement data are given in Table .

Syntheses. The published route to [py(CH2pz)2] (L) used by other research groups10 involved several preliminary steps and the use of a biphasic reaction between 2,6-bis(chloromethyl)pyridine and pyrazole in the presence of a phase transfer catalyst. We choose a simpler approach to the same ligand, and L was readily synthesized (Scheme ) by tosylation of 2,6-pyridine-dimethanol followed by the reaction of the ditosylate intermediate with two equivalents of sodium pyrazolate. The pure ligand is a pale yellow oil, soluble in water, alcohols, and other organic solvents, and reacts readily with metallic salts (in either the absence or the presence of additional ligands) (Scheme ). Reaction of L with BiI3 leads to a molecular species, [py(CH2pz)2](BiI3), with all nitrogen containing rings coordinated to bismuth. The reaction of L with AgOTf or K2[PtCl4] produced in both cases cationic species, either as infinite single-stranded chains of the formula {Ag[py(CH2pz)2]+}∞ or as discrete {PtCl[py(CH2pz)2]}+ moieties, with triflate and tetrafluoroborate anions as counterions, respectively.

Results

 Syntheses. The published route to [py(CH2pz)2] (L) used by other research groups10 involved several preliminary steps and the use of a biphasic reaction between 2,6-bis(chloromethyl)pyridine and pyrazole in the presence of a phase transfer catalyst. We choose a simpler approach to the same ligand, and L was readily synthesized (Scheme ) by tosylation of 2,6-pyridine-dimethanol followed by the reaction of the ditosylate intermediate with two equivalents of sodium pyrazolate. The pure ligand is a pale yellow oil, soluble in water, alcohols, and other organic solvents, and reacts readily with metallic salts (in either the absence or the presence of additional ligands) (Scheme ). Reaction of L with BiI3 leads to a molecular species, [py(CH2pz)2](BiI3), with all nitrogen containing rings coordinated to bismuth. The reaction of L with AgOTf or K2[PtCl4] produced in both cases cationic species, either as infinite single-stranded chains of the formula {Ag[py(CH2pz)2]+}∞ or as discrete {PtCl[py(CH2pz)2]}+ moieties, with triflate and tetrafluoroborate anions as counterions, respectively.

elements.content: The reaction between L and Cd(BF4)2 afforded the expected compound {Cd[py(CH2pz)2]2}(BF4)2 in a microcrystalline form. Several attempts to perform a structural investigation established the coordination of two ligands to the metallic center in an octahedral conformation, but a complete analysis was hampered by the lack of suitable single crystals. When the reaction was carried out in the presence of the additional ligands 4,4‘-bipyridine or 1,10-phenathroline, all of the ligands were found within the crystal, although not all of them bonded to cadmium. In the former case, crystals of the formula {Cd[py(CH2pz)2]2}(BF4)2·(4,4‘-bipy)·0.5H2O (4) were obtained where the added coligand simply cocrystallizes with the metal complex. In the latter case, crystals of the formula {Cd[phen]3}2(BF4)4·[py(CH2pz)2]·5H2O (5) form in which the added coligand coordinates directly to the cadmium.

elements.content: Molecular and Crystal Structures. The molecular structure of [py(CH2pz)2](BiI3) (1) is represented in Figure . The structure consists of one py(CH2pz)2 ligand chelating the BiI3 moiety in a facial bonding mode. This arrangement orients the two pyrazolyl rings on the same side of the plane of the pyridyl ring, a rare arrangement for this ligand (vide infra). The N(11)−Bi and N(21)−Bi distances are 2.557(3) and 2.647(4) Å, respectively, as observed with other complexes of BiI3 with nitrogen containing heterocycles as ligands (for selected bonds lengths and angles, see Table ). The pyridyl nitrogen is also connected to the bismuth atom, but the distance is longer, at 2.818(3) Å, and is therefore best described as a secondary bond. The average Bi−I distance is 2.9704 Å, similar to other complexes of BiI3.

The [py(CH2pz)2](BiI3) molecules are associated into dimers through Bi−I secondary bonds (Bi−I distance = 3.62 Å), a common feature with these types of compounds. The dimers are pictured in Figure , with the Bi−I secondary bonds shown as blue dotted lines. Summing all structural features, the bismuth(III) is seven coordinate, with five strong covalent bonds and two secondary bonds, leading to an overall BiN3I4 central core with a facial type arrangement of the N3 donor set (see Figures and ).

elements.content: Further organization of the dimers within the crystal deserves attention. The dimers are associated in chains running along the b-axis of the unit cell through an interaction that resembles the “aryl embrace” and the “pyrazolyl embrace” supramolecular motifs. Two pyrazolyl rings are involved in a parallel displaced π−π stacking, with the dihedral angle between the rings of 0.0° and with the displacement angle (measured by the angle between the pyrazolyl ring normal and the centroid−centroid vector) of 20° and a perpendicular distance between the rings of 3.7 Å. The H(22) atoms (situated on the pyrazolyl rings involved in the aforementioned π−π stacking) are pointed toward the pyridyl ring with the following geometrical details:  H−centroid distance = 2.9 Å, C−centroid distance = 3.8 Å, and the C−H−centroid angle = 147°. This interaction and the subsequent arrangement of the dimers in chains are represented in Figure .

elements.content: The structure of {Ag[py(CH2pz)2](OTf)·CH3CN}∞ (2) consists of single-stranded cationic chains, made up by a bridging mode of the ligand to silver(I). One pyrazolyl ring and the central pyridyl ring coordinate to one silver atom, while the second pyrazolyl ring is coordinated to a second silver atom, as pictured in Figure . The acetonitrile molecule is not coordinated to the silver. This bridging structure was anticipated as earlier work had shown that silver(I) complexes can produce sophisticated coordination architectures and supramolecular arrays

elements.content: The average Ag−N distance is 2.55 Å (see Table ), with the silver in an almost trigonal planar arrangement, the sum of N−Ag−N angles being 356°. The triflate anion is not coordinated to the silvers, the shortest Ag−O distance being 2.983(4) Å, too long to be considered a silver−oxygen contact. However, the triflate anions are situated in the proximity of the chains, with a short C(7)−H(7a)···O(1) contact at 2.15 Å (the C···O distance is 3.12 Å) and a C−H−O angle of 168°. A distinct feature of the chain (also shown in Figure ) is the intrastrand, somewhat distorted parallel orientation of the pyridyl moiety and pyrazolyl ring that contains the N(11) atom. The centroid−centroid distance is 3.6 Å, and the perpendicular distance between the rings is 3.4 Å. The dihedral angle between the planes is 13° with a slip angle between the planes of 18°. This deviation from an ideal stacked geometry (a dihedral angle of 0°) arises from structural constrains of the covalent body of the strand; therefore, the overall shape of the strand is based on the interplay between the observed π−π stacking and geometric constraints imposed by coordination of the ligand to the silver atoms.

elements.content: The strands are arranged within the crystal with the aromatic rings oriented in such a manner that two pyridyl rings are stacked in a parallel displaced fashion with the nitrogen atoms being oriented in opposite directions. The dihedral angle between the planes is 0.0°, the displacement angle (measured by the angle between the pyridyl ring normal and the centroid−centroid vector) is 13.4°, and the perpendicular distance between the rings is 3.49 Å. The H(4) atoms (situated on the stacked pyridyl rings) are pointed toward the pyrazolyl rings that contain the N(11) atoms, with the following geometrical details:  H−centroid distance = 2.65 Å, C−centroid distance = 3.45 Å, and the C−H−centroid angle = 142°. The interaction between two strands, a detailed representation of the interaction, and four strands associated through this type of aryl embrace are pictured in Figure , where the black double arrows indicate where the π−π stacking interaction resides.

elements.content: We wished to analyze the robustness of this aryl embrace motif with a central metallic atom that has an octahedral coordination preference. We choose cadmium as the metallic center, and the reaction between the Cd(BF4)2 and L afforded a compound of the formula{Cd[py(CH2pz)2]2}(BF4)2, but further structural analysis was hampered by the lack of suitable single crystals, although a preliminary analysis established the coordination of two ligands to the metallic center in an octahedral conformation. However, when the reaction between Cd(BF4)2 and L was carried out in the presence of the N-donor ligands 4,4‘-bipyridine and 1,10-phenanthroline, suitable single crystals were obtained. When the coligand was 4,4‘-bipyridine (4,4‘-bipy), crystals of the formula {Cd[py(CH2pz)2]2}(BF4)2·(4,4‘-bipy)·0.5H2O (4) were obtained. The cationic unit is formed by the meridional coordination of two ligands to one cadmium center as pictured in Figure . Each ligand has its pyrazolyl ring oriented above and below the plane of the pyridyl ring, as observed in the platinum complex 3. The cadmium−nitrogen distances are practically equal at 2.335(2), 2.344(2), and 2.421(2) Å (Table ). The slightly shorter Cd−N distances involve the pyrazolyl rings; therefore, the geometry around cadmium is best described as a slightly elongated, along the N(1)−Cd(1)−N(1A) axis, octahedron.

elements.content: In contrast to other cases, the 4,4‘-bipyridine ligand is not coordinated to the cadmium center but further organizes the supramolecular cationic units in a two-dimensional network by the means of the same embrace motif:  Each 4,4‘-bipyridine molecule is involved in a π−π stacking interaction with two pyridyl rings within two ligands L as it can be seen in Figure . The distance between the two pyridyl centroids is 3.5 Å, and the slip angle is 16° with a perpendicular distance between the rings of 3.4 Å. The H(35) atoms are oriented toward a pyrazolyl ring at a distance of 3.0 Å, with an C−H−centroid angle of 149.2°. This structural feature makes each pyridyl ring within the ligand L double sandwiched, once by a neighboring, chemically identical pyridyl ring and once by a pyridyl ring within the 4,4‘-bipyridine molecule. In both cases, the pyrazolyl rings act as proton acceptors:  the N(11)/N(12), containing pyrazolyl rings act as proton acceptors within the interaction that connects the cationic units, and the N(21)/N(22), containing pyrazolyl rings act as proton acceptors within the interaction that involve the bipyridyl unit.

elements.content: In the complexes described here, the py(CH2pz)2 ligand was found coordinated to the metallic center in four out of five cases. In compounds 1−3, where L was the only species with donor capabilities present in the system, the ligand acted tridentate, the resulting compounds being either discrete species (1 and 3) or a coordination polymer (2). In compounds 4 and 5, where there are two types of ligands present, the molecular structures were dictated by an interplay of the preference of the cadmium center for octahedral geometry, the basicity of the ligands, and the overall packing of the units in the crystals. In the case of 4, the ligating molecule was L. Although 4,4‘-bipyridine is more basic, octahedral coordination of the cadmium by this linear ligand would generate an architecture with large (ca. 11 Å × 11 Å) voids. Rather than coordinate to the cadmium, the 4,4‘-bipyridine moieties act as “glue” between the cationic building blocks in the supramolecular structure. In the case of 5, the more basic phenanthroline ligand coordinated to cadmium and the less basic L acts as the “glue” between the [Cd(phen)3]2+ units in the supramolecular structure.
elements.clean_text:
Discussion

In the complexes described here, the py(CH2pz)2 ligand was found coordinated to the metallic center in four out of five cases. In compounds 1-3, where L was the only species with donor capabilities present in the system, the ligand acted tridentate, the resulting compounds being either discrete species (1 and 3) or a coordination polymer (2). In compounds 4 and 5, where there are two types of ligands present, the molecular structures were dictated by an interplay of the preference of the cadmium center for octahedral geometry, the basicity of the ligands, and the overall packing of the units in the crystals. In the case of 4, the ligating molecule was L. Although 4,4‘-bipyridine is more basic, octahedral coordination of the cadmium by this linear ligand would generate an architecture with large (ca. 11 Å × 11 Å) voids. Rather than coordinate to the cadmium, the 4,4‘-bipyridine moieties act as "glue" between the cationic building blocks in the supramolecular structure. In the case of 5, the more basic phenanthroline ligand coordinated to cadmium and the less basic L acts as the "glue" between the [Cd(phen)3]2+ units in the supramolecular structure.

elements.content: Despite the large differences found within the central cores of the molecular and cationic structures, the supramolecular structures described here have a common organizational feature of the “embrace” between the pyridyl and the pyrazolyl rings, as shown in Figures , , , , and 12. The embrace consists of two rings involved in a coplanar π−π stacking interaction with its respective symmetry-related counterpart of another building block. The pyridyl or pyrazolyl groups are aligned such that the heteroatoms are in the energetically favorable head-to-tail arrangement, oriented in opposite directions. Each of these rings also acts as hydrogen donors in C−H···π interactions, with two other adjacent rings acting as proton-accepting groups. The geometric parameters of each of these intercationic interactions are well within the accepted ranges for the separate interactions, as well as for their combination.

The pyridyl or pyrazolyl groups are aligned such that the heteroatoms are in the energetically favorable head-to-tail arrangement, oriented in opposite directions. Each of these rings also acts as hydrogen donors in C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions, with two other adjacent rings acting as proton-accepting groups. The geometric parameters of each of these intercationic interactions are well within the accepted ranges for the separate interactions, as well as for their combination.

elements.content: Analysis of the synthon indicates that the π−π and C−H···π components of the embrace influence the geometric parameters of each. A perfect face-to-face π−π stacking is precluded by the presence of the C−H···π component of the embrace. An ideal C−H···π interaction would be such that the donor−hydrogen−acceptor angle would be 180°, an impossible value given the fact that the proton donors are involved in the π−π stacking interaction. The same characteristics were found when the “pure” quadruple pyrazolyl9 or aryl6b embrace motifs were studied.

An ideal C-H⋅⋅⋅π interaction would be such that the donor-hydrogen-acceptor angle would be 180°, an impossible value given the fact that the proton donors are involved in the π-π stacking interaction. The same characteristics were found when the "pure" quadruple pyrazolyl9 or aryl6b embrace motifs were studied.

elements.content: It has been established that the order of stability in the interaction of two π systems is π deficient−π deficient > π deficient−π rich > π rich−π rich. A nitrogen heteroatom within an aromatic ring acts as an electron withdrawing perturbation. Pyridine, bipyridines, phenanthrolines, and other aromatic nitrogen heterocycles are known as electron deficient ring systems, and coordination of the nitrogen heteroatom to a metal further enhances the electron withdrawing effect. In four cases (2−5), the pyridyl ring was the stacked ring and the pyrazolyl rings acted as proton acceptors. Compound 1 is the only case where the roles were reversed and stacked rings were the pyrazolyl rings. In this compound, the Npyridyl−Bi bond is long at 2.818(3) Å, a value greater than the sum of their covalent radii (2.56 Å) but smaller than the sum of their van der Waals radii (3.75 Å). In contrast, the pyrazolyl rings are covalently bonded to the bismuth(III) center and therefore have a decreased π-electron density, which turns them into the favored candidates for the π−π stacking component of the embrace. Thus, we have shown that aromatic nitrogen heterocycles coordinated to metals are more likely to undergo π−π stacking interactions than the pyrazolyl rings bonded to metals, although this trend can be reversed if the pyrazolyl ring is strongly bonded to a metal and the pyridyl ring is not.

Thus, we have shown that aromatic nitrogen heterocycles coordinated to metals are more likely to undergo π-π stacking interactions than the pyrazolyl rings bonded to metals, although this trend can be reversed if the pyrazolyl ring is strongly bonded to a metal and the pyridyl ring is not.

elements.content: Unfortunately, a serious statistical analysis of this interaction was precluded by the small number of metal complexes bearing the py(CH2pz)2 ligand. In the first step of an investigation (CSD, version 5.25, November 2003, 298097 entries), all “one arm” py[CH2(3,5-R2pz)]M groups were identified (R = H or other organic radical, pz = pyrazolyl ring; M = any metal or metalloid bound to a pyrazolyl and/or pyridyl group nitrogen atom). This search yielded only 35 hits. Further restrictions then followed from the geometric parameters accepted for π−π stacking and C−H···π interactions. Thus, a centroid−centroid distance range of 3.0−4.6 Å along with a dihedral angle, α, range of 0−20° was defined to encompass either intra- or intermolecular π−π stacking interactions involving the pyrazolyl groups. The C−H···π interaction was allowed to retain a H−centroid interval between 2.0 and 3.3 Å along with a corresponding C−H−centroid angle (θ) range between 110 and 180°. As a result of these geometric restrictions, the hydrogen atoms involved in the C−H···π interactions are always oriented above the π cloud of the corresponding hydrogen accepting pyrazolyl ring. Therefore, no other parameters were necessary for defining the C−H···π interaction, as in other cases. From these combined restraints, six crystal structures from the previously obtained subset of 35 were found to contain a mixed aryl−pyrazolyl embrace. It is worth noting that the search described here, using only “one arm” of the ligand, also extracted other more complex species, i.e., {phen[CH2(pz)]2}. When the search was conducted specifically on the ligand discussed here, only 25 examples were found, five of which contain a mixed aryl−pyrazolyl embrace.

elements.content: In all cases discussed here, regardless of which rings were involved in the π−π stacking component of the embrace, they were always of the same type; that is, they always had the same number of atoms within the ring. In none of the cases studied here or in the literature was a pyridyl ring stacked over a pyrazolyl ring. This symmetry requirement is one of the common denominators found in all embraces and could be the starting point for further studies of this type of mixed embraces.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In all cases discussed here, regardless of which rings were involved in the π-π stacking component of the embrace, they were always of the same type; that is, they always had the same number of atoms within the ring. In none of the cases studied here or in the literature was a pyridyl ring stacked over a pyrazolyl ring. This symmetry requirement is one of the common denominators found in all embraces and could be the starting point for further studies of this type of mixed embraces.

elements.content: The building blocks were associated by cooperative π−π and C···H−π interactions. To date, such interactions (aryl embraces) have been systematically analyzed in compounds bearing aromatic cycles containing the same number of atoms within all of the rings involved in the interaction. We systematically analyzed here for the first time similar embraces that appear within chemical species bearing rings containing different numbers of atoms within the ring, i.e., in chemical species containing a pyridyl ring (six atoms) and a pyrazolyl ring (five atoms). This combined set of interactions between pyridyl and pyrazolyl rings has been entitled aryl−pyrazolyl embrace. While the data contained within this paper serve to demonstrate the viability of the aryl−pyrazolyl embrace as a synthon for the construction of supramolecular edifices, their crystal structures also serve as a useful example of the importance of other noncovalent interactions for the organization into higher dimensionality architectures. The study of systems such as the one presented here can serve as the bases for the rational design of new solid materials with promising useful properties, since this work shows that this structure directing motif comprised from embraces of the π-containing rings is of a general occurrence and not restricted only to aromatic rings of Dance's type.
elements.clean_text: The building blocks were associated by cooperative π-π and C⋅⋅⋅H-π interactions. To date, such interactions (aryl embraces) have been systematically analyzed in compounds bearing aromatic cycles containing the same number of atoms within all of the rings involved in the interaction. We systematically analyzed here for the first time similar embraces that appear within chemical species bearing rings containing different numbers of atoms within the ring, i.e., in chemical species containing a pyridyl ring (six atoms) and a pyrazolyl ring (five atoms). This combined set of interactions between pyridyl and pyrazolyl rings has been entitled aryl-pyrazolyl embrace. While the data contained within this paper serve to demonstrate the viability of the aryl-pyrazolyl embrace as a synthon for the construction of supramolecular edifices, their crystal structures also serve as a useful example of the importance of other noncovalent interactions for the organization into higher dimensionality architectures. The study of systems such as the one presented here can serve as the bases for the rational design of new solid materials with promising useful properties, since this work shows that this structure directing motif comprised from embraces of the π-containing rings is of a general occurrence and not restricted only to aromatic rings of Dance's type.

Synthesis of [py(CH 2 pz) 2 ] (L). To a stirred solution of 2,6-pyridinedimethanol (2.78 g, 0.020 mol) and NaOH (8.0 g, 0.20 mol) in THF/water (75/75 mL) was added a solution of p-toluenesulfonyl chloride (7.61 g, 0.040 mol) in THF (75 mL) at 0 °C. After 4 h of stirring, the mixture was poured into 200 mL of water and extracted with methylene chloride (4 × 75 mL). The organic phase was washed with saturated aqueous NaCl solution and distilled water and dried (Na2SO4), and then, the solvent was removed under vacuum to afford 2,6-pyridine-dimethylene-ditosylate (7.25 g, 81%) as a white powder. In a separate flask (under a nitrogen atmosphere) to a suspension of NaH (0.77 g, 0.032 mol) in dry THF (50 mL) was added dropwise, at 0 °C, a solution of pyrazole (2.20 g, 0.032 mol) in dry THF (50 mL). After 15 min of stirring, a clear solution of Napz was obtained. To this solution was added a solution of pyridine-ditosylate derivative (7.25 g, 0.016 mol) in dry THF (75 mL), the mixture was stirred overnight and filtered, and the solvent was removed to afford 3.52 g (91%) of pure ligand as a pale yellow oil that solidifies in time. 1H NMR (acetone-d 6):  δ:  7.77, 7.50 (d, d, J = 2.1, 1.5 Hz, 2, 2H, 3,5-H pz), 7.64 (t, J = 8.31 Hz, 1H, py), 6.85 (d, J = 8.31, 2H, py), 6.30 (dd, J = 2.1, J = 1.5 Hz, 2H, 4-H pz), 5.45 (s, 4H, PyCH 2 pz). Calcd for C13H13N5:  C, 65.25; H, 5.48. Found:  C, 65.48; H, 5.18.

Synthesis and Crystallization of [py(CH 2 pz) 2 ](BiI 3 ) (1). To a stirred solution of BiI3 (0.147 g, 0.25 mmol) in boiling acetonitrile (50 mL) was added a solution of L (0.059 g, 0.25 mmol) in acetonitrile (25 mL). After 15 min of stirring, the orange−red solution was filtered to remove any solid material and placed in a beaker covered with aluminum foil. Red−orange single crystals formed overnight, which were filtered and air-dried (the yield of crystalline material was 0.124 g, 60%). 1H NMR (acetone-d 6, all br):  δ:  7.55 (4H, 3,5-H pz), 7.32 (1H, py), 6.51 (2H, py), 6.02 (2H, 4-H pz), 5.65 (4H, PyCH 2pz). Anal. calcd for C13H13BiI3N5:  C, 18.84; H, 1.58. Found:  C, 19.05; H, 1.23.

Synthesis and Crystallization of {Ag[py(CH 2 pz) 2 ](OTf)·CH 3 CN} ∞ (2). To a stirred solution of AgO3SCF3 (AgOTf) (0.064 g, 0.25 mmol) in acetonitrile (10 mL) was added a solution of L (0.059 g, 0.25 mmol) in acetonitrile (5 mL). After 15 min of stirring, the clear solution was left to stand undisturbed. Colorless single crystals deposited after several days, which were filtered and air-dried (the yield of crystalline material was 0.093 g, 76%). 1H NMR (acetone-d 6):  δ:  8.12, 7.78, (d, d, J = 2.3, 1.7 Hz, 2, 2H, 3,5-H pz), 8.06 (t, J = 7.8, 1H, py), 7.62 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 2H, py), 6.44 (dd, J = 2.3, J = 1.7 Hz, 2H, 4-H pz), 5.85 (s, 4H, PyCH 2pz), 2.78 (s, 3H, CH 3CN). Anal. calcd for C16H16AgF3N6O3S:  C, 35.77; H, 3.00. Found:  C, 35.34; H, 2.53.

Synthesis and Crystallization of {PtCl[py(CH 2 pz) 2 ]}(BF 4 ) (3). To a suspension of K2[PtCl4] (0.104 g, 0.25 mmol) in nitromethane was added a solution of L (0.059 g, 0.25 mmol) in nitromethane and an excess of solid NaBF4 (0.109 g, 1.0 mmol). The mixture was heated at reflux overnight and filtered, and the solvent was evaporated, to leave an off white solid. The solid was taken back in the minimum amount of nitromethane and crystallized by diethyl ether vapor diffusion (yield of crystalline material was 0.065 g, 47%). 1H NMR (acetone-d 6):  δ:  8.43 (t, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H, py), 8.37, 8.04 (d, d, J = 3.0, 1.8 Hz, 2, 2H, 3,5-H pz), 8.10 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 2H, py), 6.69 (d, J = 5.4 Hz, 2H, 4-H pz), 6.69 (s, 4H, PyCH 2pz). Anal. calcd for C13H13BClF4N5Pt:  C, 28.05; H, 2.35. Found:  C, 28.12; H, 2.38.

Synthesis and Crystallization of {Cd[py(CH 2 pz) 2 ] 2 }(BF 4 ) 2 ·[4,4‘-bipy] · 0.5H 2 O (4). To a stirred solution of Cd(BF4)2 in water (45 wt % solution, d = 1.485) (0.107 mL, 0.25 mmol) was added a solution of L (0.059 g, 0.25 mmol) in ethanol (5 mL) and then a solution of 4,4‘-bipy (0.039 g, 0.25 mmol) in ethanol (5 mL). After 15 min of stirring, the clear solution was left to stand undisturbed. Colorless single crystals deposited after several days, which were filtered and air-dried (the yield of crystalline material was 0.147 g, 63%). 1H NMR (acetone-d 6, all br):  δ 8.88 (4H, bipy) 7.95, 7.85 (4,4H, 3,5-H pz), 7.78 (4H, bipy), 6.42 (6H, py), 6.02 (4H, 4-H pz), 5.85 (8H, PyCH 2pz). Anal. calcd for C36H35B2CdF8N12O0.5:  C, 46.50; H, 3.79. Found:  C, 46.88; H, 3.89.

Synthesis and Crystallization of {Cd[phen] 3 } 2 (BF 4 ) 4 ·[py(CH 2 pz) 2 ] · 5H 2 O (5). To a stirred solution of Cd(BF4)2 in water (45 wt % solution, d = 1.485) (0.214 mL, 0.5 mmol) was added a solution of L (0.059 g, 0.25 mmol) in ethanol (5 mL) and then a solution of 1,10-phen (0.297 g, 1.5 mmol) in ethanol (5 mL). After 15 min of stirring, the clear solution was left to stand undisturbed. Colorless single crystals deposited after several days, which were filtered and air-dried (the yield of crystalline material was 0.334 g, 67%). 1H NMR (acetone-d 6):  δ 8.93 (d, J = 8.1 Hz, 12H, phen), 8.33 (s, 12H, phen), 8.02 (t, J = 8.0 Hz, 12H, phen), 7.88 (m, 12H, phen), 7.78, 7.47, (d, d, J = 2.1, 1.5 Hz, 2, 2H, 3,5-H pz), 7.68 (t, J = 5.7 Hz, 1H, py), 6.85 (d, J = 5.7 Hz, 2H, py), 6.30 (d, J = 1.8 Hz, 2H, 4-H pz), 5.45 (s, 4H, PyCH 2pz), 3.18 (s, br, 10H, H 2O). Anal. calcd for C85H71B4Cd2F16N17O5:  C, 51.49; H, 3.61. Found:  C, 51.02; H, 3.98.

Geometric Parameters Associated with the Pyrazolyl Embrace a
